content: as the horde of bug bath sets on destruction approached the city gates
you take position atop the walls side by side with the brave young men and women
tasked with protecting this town your weapons and numbers seem far too small
to a stand this attack and you must rely on your courage and wits alone if you
are to make it out alive what's up guys welcome back to another episode of black
magic crafts some of you have already jumped on the dungeon stackers bandwagon
and some of you maybe haven't yet and if you happen to have missed that episode
check it out up over somewhere over there dungeon stackers are one of the if
not the most versatile bit of terrain that you can build and use as a crafting
DM they are so versatile that people online continue to come up with unique
and original ways to use them and in fact some people have even started
making their own unique add-ons to their set recently Paul Schultz a longtime
patreon supporter and crafting extraordinaire hosted in the black magic
craft fellowship some Battlement add-ons that he made to turn his stackers into
fortress and castle walls and they blew my mind
they were so impressive that I stopped everything I was doing and built my own
set when he made his he used XPS insulation foam milled down to the most
appropriate thickness but I wanted to do my build in the most approachable
Universal way possible so I built mine simply using Dollar Tree foam core
that's the ready brand stuff that you can peel the paper off really easily
I used a hot glue gun and a knife no special tools required well that's not
entirely true there is one special tool that you will need and that is a
computer printer because I designed a printable template to help you guys
build these more easily there will be a link to that template in the description
of this video so print that bad boy out and
let's build some dungeon stacker battlements I've included two different
styles on this template so you can pick which one you like the best when you
print them out you want to make sure that they print out at the right scale
which is three inches long which should be the same as the length of your
dungeon stackers to make these templates really reusable I glued them to some
chipboard you could use something like cereal box or whatever
the idea is to glue it to something that is sturdier than just paper and then cut
it out you want to take a lot of time to do a nice clean job cutting out these
templates so that you have a perfect shape and smooth sides once the
templates are cut out you can use them over and over again to cut out as many
Battlement sides as you want and I just used the dollar store foam core I laid
the template right on top and just used it as a guide for my exacto knife the
side of the foam that is touching the template usually turns out with a nicer
cut so I like to mark the other side as the back or the inside so that when I
glue these together I have the nicer side facing out
once all my pieces were cut out I used a crumpled-up ball of aluminum foil to
give them some really nice stone texture this simple step will make painting way
easier I also made some pieces that were a little bit shorter to fit the smaller
dungeon stackers now you could leave these pieces just like this and then
paint it up they'd look a bit like concrete but I did want to make them
look like they have a bit of individual stones so I carved in some grout lines
and I did this using a fine point sharpie the reason for this is that if
you use a pen or a knife this foam core is so thin that it may become very
brittle and you're basically cutting it the Sharpie has a tiny bit of solvent in
it that just slightly melts the foam a little bit that mixed with some slight
pressure on the marker will give you a indentation to
present grout lines but one that's not so deep that you're cutting right
through the phone I then made the floor pieces and these have the same footprint
as my dungeon stackers which is three inches by two inches and some that are
two inches by two inches I made mine look like wood planks but
you could make yours look like stone tiles if you wanted the important thing
here is that I kept the paper on one side of the foam core to add a little
bit more rigidity and strength to these pieces I then got to work assembling
these and this was really simple it was just a bead of hot glue along the edge
of the floor piece and attach it to one of the sides stone pieces put the other
side on and that's it done there are some projects big chunkier
foam projects where you can get away with not doing the Mod Podge step this
isn't one of them because this foam core is so thin and I've kind of compromised
its strength by doing all that pen work it's very important to coat it with Mod
Podge or at least some sort of glue to make it harder and sturdier I kept the
paint job very simple on these but I did want them to contrast against my gray
dungeon stackers so I chose to paint the stonework in a tan motif I used this
kind of light suede as the base color for my stone and then I did some dry
brushing with a lighter tad and then a white I painted out the woodwork using a
fairly bright medium golden wood tone because I wanted these to look new not
decrepit and old after the base colors were all complete and the dry brushing
was done I moved on to the black wash and this is actually a black wash that
has a lot of brown in it and I find that this is the best way to very quickly get
some pretty realistic looking stonework it really highlights all those little
crevices and details after the wash was complete it was time
to protect these with a clear coat and again like the Mod Podge this was even
more important because these were pretty delicate pieces I was fresh out of the
Minwax polyurethane that I usually used so I turned to my Kryolan clear coat
that I use on my miniatures this stuff seems to be fairly safe on foam from my
experience but I have heard of others having it melts so if you're gonna try
it test it out first it does have the added advantage of not yellowing over
time I think these are a brilliant add-on to a set of dungeon stackers and
more than anything else they really excite me for the idea of more add-ons
and what else can we the community do with these dungeon stackers thanks again
Paul for the inspiration for this if you guys need to download the template the
link will be in the video description if you need to pick up any
fools or supplies to complete this build head on over to Blackmagic craft dot CA
there I have my essential equipment store with all of the things that I use
and recommend and purchasing through those links helps fund these videos the
other way you can fund these videos if you want to help me continue making them
for the community is by supporting Blackmagic craft on patreon that support
is the number one reason I am able to make these videos each and every week
for the community I'd love to have you as the newest member of the Blackmagic
craft fellowship that's it guys I hope you found this video informative and
inspiring if you did hit that like button and let me know in the comments
section below if you are new to the channel be sure you hit subscribe and
check out my back catalog of other terrain building videos if you're really
new to the Hobby I have a series of basics videos to help you get started
and if you got any questions post them in the comment section and I will do my
best to answer them that's it for this week guys Cheers happy crafting
